citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An adult dog was found with untreated limping. Helena, a four-year-old female Husky (m/c # 900113001982123) was
observed limping on both her right front and back legs. She walked slowly and gingerly with a noticeable limp. The
licensee noted that she hadn’t noticed the limping this morning, she has been limping on and off and she has not been
seen by the veterinarian for this issue. Untreated limping can cause pain and discomfort to the animal and can lead to
further heath issues. This dog must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an
effective treatment plan.

Primary enclosures were found with metal that had sharp points. In three primary enclosures housing approximately five
adults and four puppies had sheets of tin metal that were being used in between enclosures to prevent the dogs from
seeing each other. In one enclosure with three adult dogs, the dogs pulled the metal away from the main enclosure to
squeeze between it and their enclosure, creating a sharp edge. In another enclosure housing one adult dog the metal tin
had started to roll down creating sharp edges where if the dog jumped up it could injure his feet. The last enclosure
housing the one adult dog and four puppies had metal ties connecting the tin to the enclosure with the sharp points facing
inward posing a risk of injury if the adult dog jumped on the enclosure. Failure to maintain housing facilities in good repair
can lead to injury of the animals contained in them. The licensee must maintain housing facilities so that they are free of
sharp points that might cause injury to the animal.
To be corrected by September 10, 2025

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The facility had unkept areas. In the sheltered building, a metal table cluttered with unused bottles and treats was covered
in a thick layer of dust. Also, in the same building in the back corner an accumulation of items was starting to pile up
including dog crates, a ladder, metal grates, and other items which also had thick layers of dust covering them. In the
shed that contained the food storage there was a huge accumulation of boxes, lots of empty feed bags, and a cart with
open straw. These conditions can attract rodents and other pests. The licensee must keep the premises clean, free of
accumulation of trash, junk, waste products and discarded matter.
To be corrected by: September 10, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Moira Roberts, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An adult dog was found with untreated limping. Helena, a four-year-old female Husky (m/c # 900113001982123) was 
observed limping on both her right front and back legs. She walked slowly and gingerly with a noticeable limp. The 
licensee noted that she hadn’t noticed the limping this morning, she has been limping on and off and she has not been 
seen by the veterinarian for this issue. Untreated limping can cause pain and discomfort to the animal and can lead to 
further heath issues. This dog must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an 
effective treatment plan. 
3.6(a)(2)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Primary enclosures were found with metal that had sharp points. In three primary enclosures housing approximately five 
adults and four puppies had sheets of tin metal that were being used in between enclosures to prevent the dogs from 
seeing each other. In one enclosure with three adult dogs, the dogs pulled the metal away from the main enclosure to 
squeeze between it and their enclosure, creating a sharp edge. In another enclosure housing one adult dog the metal tin 
had started to roll down creating sharp edges where if the dog jumped up it could injure his feet. The last enclosure 
housing the one adult dog and four puppies had metal ties connecting the tin to the enclosure with the sharp points facing 
inward posing a risk of injury if the adult dog jumped on the enclosure. Failure to maintain housing facilities in good repair 
can lead to injury of the animals contained in them. The licensee must maintain housing facilities so that they are free of 
sharp points that might cause injury to the animal.  
To be corrected by September 10, 2025 
3.11(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The facility had unkept areas. In the sheltered building, a metal table cluttered with unused bottles and treats was covered 
in a thick layer of dust. Also, in the same building in the back corner an accumulation of items was starting to pile up 
including dog crates, a ladder, metal grates, and other items which also had thick layers of dust covering them. In the 
shed that contained the food storage there was a huge accumulation of boxes, lots of empty feed bags, and a cart with 
open straw. These conditions can attract rodents and other pests. The licensee must keep the premises clean, free of 
accumulation of trash, junk, waste products and discarded matter.  
To be corrected by: September 10, 2025

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Moira Roberts, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
